title: MBE honour for Barrow Lioness in New Year Honours list
body_text:
Barrow’s Georgia Stanway has been made a Member of the British Empire (MBE) alongside a host of fellow Lionesses in the New Year Honours list.
Last night, it was announced that the England women’s footballer, Georgia Stanway, 26, who is now a double European champion, has been recognised for services to association football.
Born in Barrow, Stanway, a midfielder, was part of the England team which won the UEFA European Women’s Championship in July, when they beat Spain on penalties in the final in Basel, Switzerland.
The Barrovian has been recognised in the honours list alongside her England captain, Leah Williamson, who has been made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE).
Furthermore, Stanway’s Lioness teammates Alex Greenwood, Keira Walsh, and Ella Toone have also been made MBEs, whilst their Dutch manager, Sarina Wiegman, has been awarded an honorary damehood.
Speaking to the Press Association (PA) after receiving the news, Wiegman said: “I would like to express my sincere gratitude for this honour.
“When I first arrived in England, I could never have imagined the respect and warmth I’ve experienced from the English people.
“I deeply thank the fans for their support.”
The announcement of Stanway being made an MBE follows her receiving the Freedom of Barrow at the Town Hall on December 23.
Speaking at the event, the Bayern Munich and England footballer said: “I'm so proud to be from Barrow and I'll always fly the Barrow flag - hopefully there's more achievements to come and we can keep making Barrow bigger on the map.”
Honours such as those Stanway and the Lionesses have received are announced twice a year, at new year and on the King’s official birthday.
They recognise those who have made significant contributions to Britain and public life.
Elsewhere in the New Year Honours list, the actor Idris Elba has been knighted for services to young people, and Olympic ice dancers Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean have been made Dame and Sir, respectively.
